title: [FUBAR] LB 820-2879 B no green or orange light (needs SMC)
message: If CHGR_ACIN is present and CHGR_DCIN is present and the resistance between pins 27/28 and pins 17/18 adds up to what the sense resistors' sum is, I would say time to replace U7000. Stay away from SI7149DP that thing is always fine, you can dip it in battery acid coca cola cat piss and beer and light it on fire and it will still work!

title: [FUBAR] LB 820-2879 B no green or orange light (needs SMC)
message: the chip has more load on it than anything else since PPBUS_G3H powers the entire machine, and it also has to deal with knockoff chargers and ripple on PP3V42_G3H as well as its own issues when there's water.

title: [FUBAR] LB 820-2879 B no green or orange light (needs SMC)
message:
Dude that is fucking scary. You need one strand of wire for this!!! Why do you think they call it the onewire circuit :p 

You have 3.36v on pin 5, but what about pin 4? Is it outputting voltage now?

U6901 is a logic gate that, when SMC_BC_ACOK is present, will allow PP3V42_G3H to pass to output. The idea here is that it will power U6900 which allows the charger to talk to the SMC if the ISL6259/U7000 says that it is ok for it to. So follow to the next logical step - is U6900 getting 3.4v? Is U6901 shooting out 3.4v for U6900? If not, why?

title: [FUBAR] LB 820-2879 B no green or orange light (needs SMC)
message: Resistor measures good, pin 1 on U7840 is 3.4v,  SMC_RESET_L is 3.4v on pin 13 of U7000.  I have no visible signs of damage around the U7200 but would you recommend replacing U7200 anyway? Is there some way to test if it is good?

title: [FUBAR] LB 820-2879 B no green or orange light (needs SMC)
message:
SMC_PM_G2_EN creates PP5V_S5 by telling U7200 on pin 13 to turn on PP5V_S5. Do you have PP5V_S5? If you do, pin 13 can go away. 

Check for a short to ground on PP3V3_S5. If no short to ground, remove Q7221 and tell me if PP3V3_S5 comes up.

title: [FUBAR] LB 820-2879 B no green or orange light (needs SMC)
message: I do not have pp5v_s5 it measures 2.2v-3.8v fluctuating. Removed Q7221 and no change

title: [FUBAR] LB 820-2879 B no green or orange light (needs SMC)
message: Q7221 is related to a different rail. If SMC_PM_G2_EN is not fluctuating, but PP5V_S5 is fluctuating, it's a safe bet your issue is either with U7200(likely) or U7840(less likely, but still possible). You have green light to replace U7200! Bonus points if you don't burn the fan or speaker connector.

title: [FUBAR] LB 820-2879 B no green or orange light (needs SMC)
message:
So we're clear, those are DC voltage measurements, and not diode mode measurements, right?

If so, SMC_PM_G2_EN is too low, which points to an SMC issue, U7840 pulling it down, or U7200 pulling it down. At this point since you've already replaced U7200, my guess is bad SMC.

Could be possible that the u7200 I replaced was bad? There was very little liquid spill on the machine, I pulled the U7200 off a donor board from china. I feel like I might be missing something from my inexperience , that maybe effecting diagnosis. Having g3hot and the 12v rail just seems like the problem might be the technician. :)
The PP5V_S5_LDO with power plugged in, checked at probe point 650 reads from dc voltage of 2.8v to 3.6v fluctuating rapidly and at SMC_PM_G2_EN its basically nothing

title: [FUBAR] LB 820-2879 B no green or orange light (needs SMC)
message:
I can only guess that SMC_PM_G2_EN is 0v because you've never posted a real number. :(

Anything is possible, but SMC_PM_G2_EN being 0v is your main issue here. That should be at 3.4v immediately. My guess here is SMC if SMC_RESET_L is present as well as PP3V42_G3H. You need SMC_PM_G2_EN to create PP5V_S5 and get the ball rolling with everything else.

title: [FUBAR] LB 820-2879 B no green or orange light (needs SMC)
message:
Ok, louis I am responding to your video today on success.
My daughter was able to micro solder on this board. (she has never done that before)
We were able to get green light on the charger by running a wire to fix the one wire circuit. (first wire was hideous, but the second one was much nicer) Have never done that before. 
We where able to get the 12v circuit running.
Successfully soldered the ISL6259 (took three tries:o)
We where not able to get the 5v up because of the SMC, however It was a great success for us at least because we are learning how to problem solve these boards.

I used to send all my boards to your favorite company (L2 Computer) :o I sent them enough that I was getting them at $180
Although I didn't get this board to work, I didn't send it to them either. Another success!
Eventually, We will learn more and have even greater success

Thanks for all you guys are doing!
